metadata.case_name: Appellant Company v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Appellant, a limited company, is owner of building constructed on Plot No. 7, Church Gate Reclamation, Bombay, fitted up with furniture and fixtures for running as a hotel.

By lease dated August 30, 1949, appellant let out the fully equipped and furnished building to Voyantzis for term of six years certain from December 9, 1946, for running a hotel and ancillary purposes; monthly rent Rs. 5,950 for building and hire Rs. 5,000 for furniture and fixtures.
For assessment year 1953-54, Income-tax Officer assessed income from building under s. 9 and from furniture/fixtures under s. 12.

Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal held rent from building assessable only under s. 12 with allowances in sub-s. 4 where letting furniture/fixtures indispensable to letting building, but not so here, confirmed s. 9 for building.

Income-tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed authorities below; allowances in s. 12(4) only where letting building incidental to letting furniture/fixtures, not here; rejected s. 10 as specific head s. 9 applies, cited United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. CIT.
Tribunal at appellant's request stated case under s. 66(1) to Bombay High Court on question: Whether income from letting building properly computed under s. 9, 10 or 12.
Bombay High Court answered: Income from building under s. 9, from furniture/fixtures under s. 12, no part under s. 10.
Appellant never carried on hotel business in premises or otherwise.
Lease clauses: Lessee to use premises, furniture/fixtures for running hotel etc.; lessor to provide/maintain furniture etc., paint building, insure; renewal options; fire damage provisions.

legal_issues.text: Whether income derived from letting of the building constructed on Plot No. 7 is properly to be computed under section 9, 10 or under section 12 of the Income-tax Act, 1922.
Whether letting out of fully equipped hotel building amounts to business income under s. 10.
Whether letting of building and furniture/fixtures is inseparable so as to attract s. 12(4) allowances for building income.

petitioner_arguments.text: Entire income should be assessed under s. 10 as income of business, as letting out commercial asset (fully equipped hotel) is business; alternatively under s. 12 as residuary source with allowances in sub-ss. 3 and 4.
Letting out totality of assets is business of assessee; lease covenants and company objects show carrying on business.

respondent_arguments.text: Building income under s. 9 as specific section; furniture under s. 12; s. 12(4) inapplicable as primary letting of building, not incidental to furniture.
Inseparable letting under s. 12(4) means machinery/plant/furniture by nature inseparable from building or primary letting of furniture with building incidental.
Lease renewal and fire clauses treat building and furniture separately.

court_reasoning.text: Heads of income in ss. 6-12 mutually exclusive; income from owned building taxable under s. 9 on annual value irrespective of rent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot tax under s. 12 if s. 9 or s. 10 applies.

court_reasoning.text: Letting not business under s. 10: Appellant never ran hotel; exploitation of property by owner, not business; distinguished cases of prior business operation or working concerns.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Letting commercial asset not inherently business; view from businessman's perspective.

court_reasoning.text: S. 12(4) applies to owner's inseparable letting of building with furniture/plant/machinery; takes building income out of s. 9 into residuary s. 12 for allowances under s. 10(2)(iv-vi).
court_reasoning.key_observation: S. 12(4) has effect only if building rent treated as residuary income when inseparably let.

court_reasoning.text: Inseparable letting from parties' intention: Intended joint enjoyment for single purpose (hotel); one not let without other; separate rents irrelevant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Lease cl. 1(a),(h) show building/furniture for running hotel together; other clauses do not separate.

holdings.text: Income from letting not business under s. 10.
Letting of building and furniture/fixtures inseparable under s. 12(4); building rent computed under s. 12 with sub-s. 4 allowances; furniture under s. 12 sub-s. 3; not under s. 9.

precedents_cited.case_name: United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Heads of income mutually exclusive; specific head prevails over residuary.

precedents_cited.case_name: East India Housing and Land Development Trust Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Income from shops/stalls is property income under s. 9 despite company objects of developing markets.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Mangalagiri Sri Umamaheswara Gin and Rice Factory Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Letting equipped rice mill (never worked) business; but pre-s.12(4), focused on wear/tear of machinery.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Bosotto Brothers Limited, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Letting hotel previously run by assessee; bound by Mangalagiri; pre-s.12(4); not letting business undertaking.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Heads of income; s.9 for property annual value; s.10 business profits/allowances; s.12 residuary with sub-s.3/4 allowances for hire/inseparable letting.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; rent from building computed under s.12 with sub-s.4 allowances, furniture/fixtures under s.12 sub-s.3; no part under s.9 or s.10.
outcome.relief_granted: Appellant entitled to s.12(4) allowances on building rent.

key_quotes.text: Whether a particular letting is business has to be decided in the circumstances of each case... from a businessmans point of view to find out whether the letting was the doing of a business or the exploitation of his property by an owner.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for business income from letting.

key_quotes.text: Inseparability... arising from the intention of the parties... Was it the intention... that the two should be enjoyed together? ... Would one have been let alone?
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Clause 1(a) [lessee covenant]: To use the demised premises and the said furniture and fixtures for the purpose of running hotel...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Evidence of joint intention for hotel use.
